clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Transparent, Self-drying Silicone Gel on the Treatment of Hypertrophic Abdominal Scars
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Transparent, Self-drying Silicone Gel on the Treatment of Hypertrophic Abdominal Scars

brief_summary.textblock: Keloids and hypertrophic scars are a common subject of dermatologic consultations. Therapeutic management of such conditions remains challenging because of their high rate of recurrence and lack of curative treatment.

detailed_description.textblock: Silicone gel Sheeting (SGS) is one treatment modality that has proven effective for treatment of hypertrophic scar. One disadvantage of SGS is its application technique. To be effective, SGS must be applied on the scar for at least 12 hours daily. Topical silicone gel is a novel therapy that has shown promising result on scar prevention. However, the efficacy and safety of topical silicone gel for treatment of hypertrophic scar has not been confirmed.

primary_outcome.time_frame: 1, 2 and 5 months after initiation of treatment

secondary_outcome.measure: Clinical assessment on overall scar appearance
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 1, 2 and 5 months after initiation of treatment

intervention.description: Topical silicone gel will be applied to the scar twice daily for a period of 8 weeks
Topical petrolatum gel will be applied to the scar twice daily for a period of 8 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- subjects at least 18 years old
- subjects with hypertrophic abdominal scar
- Have not received treatment on the scar at least 1 month prior to the enrollment.
Exclusion Criteria:
- subject who has previous history of silicone allergy
- subject who smoke cigarette
- subject who was treated with x-rays irradiation in the past
